body.p:
Glasgow Apl 15 1864
To His Excellency
Tho E. Bramlette,
Dear Sir,

Mrs Elizabeth Dunn visits Frankfort for the purpose of seeing her son, who is a convict in the penitentiary, & of appealing to you in his behalf. Wm Dunn, his son, is a private in the 34th Ky Infantry, & served for some time in it, but as I understand, he got drunk in Louisville, played cards, with a negro for a watch, & won its, & the negro refusing to give it up, he knocked him down & took it away from him, was indicted & tried in the Jefferson Circuit Court on a charge of robbery & convicted.

His mother is old, & resides here, though the family are refugees from Middle Tennessee, driven from home on account of this devotion to the Union. Wm Dunn served for about two years in some regiment not recollected by his mother, & then joined the 34th Ky. with his father, who is now 55 years old. I hope you Excellency
will give his case some consideration & that you may find it consistent with your sense of duty to pardon him & restore him to his regiment. He can do his country more good fighting for it, then in the penitentiary, if the facts are as represented, I think he is already sufficiently punished.

I saw him when I was in Frankfort & he does not look to me like a bad man, & if you had time to see him yourself, I think he would impress you favorably. I know your time is very much employed, but hope you may spare enough to make happy the heart of this old lady, consistently with your views of official duty.
I need not state, that I have no personal knowledge of the facts of his case,

Very Respectfully
Your Truly
Wm Sampson

Jefferson Cir Ct
vs
Wm Dunn
Issue Pardon specifically that it is upon consideration that he immediately rejoins his Regiment and continues to serve his time faithfully therein
Enquire at the Penitentiary for the term of his & the court
